qas.question: What kind of substance is an alloy?
What happens when an alloy is mixed with a molten base?

answers.text: they will be soluble, dissolving into the mixture

qas.question: What is an alloy composed of?
What other metal is impure like alloy?
What is a mixture of impure substances?
What is a pure substance that retains the characteristics of a metal?
What desirable characteristic doesn't alloy and an impure metal have?
Mixing any to what produces an alloy
What other metal is pure like an alloy?

context: <b4_0><b5_0>An alloy<b5_0/><b4_0/> is a mixture of either pure or fairly pure chemical elements, which forms an <a0_0>impure<a0_0/> substance (admixture) that retains the characteristics of a metal. An alloy is distinct from an impure metal, such as <a3_0><b8_0>wrought iron<b8_0/><a3_0/>, in that, with an alloy, the <b6_0>added impurities<b6_0/> are usually desirable and will typically have some useful benefit. Alloys are made by mixing <a2_0>two or more <b7_0>elements<a2_0/>;<b7_0/> at least one of which being a metal. This is usually called the primary metal or the base metal, and the name of this metal may also be the name of the alloy. The other constituents may or may not be metals but, when mixed with the molten base, <a1_0>they will be soluble, dissolving into the mixture<a1_0/>.
